DataElement.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Or Myelodysplastic Syndrome Cytogenetic Response Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The disease status or response to treatment of acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndome based on a cytogenetic evaluation.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Disease Response Domain Acute Myeloid Leukemia Or Myelodysplastic Syndrome Cytogenetic Response
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain for disease response evaluations._A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification)._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A clonal hematopoietic disorder characterized by dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in one or more of the hematopoietic cell lines. The dysplasia may be accompanied by an increase in myeloblasts, but the number is less than 20%, which, according to the WHO guidelines, is the requisite threshold for the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. It may occur de novo or as a result of exposure to alkylating agents and/or radiotherapy. (WHO, 2001)_An evaluation of the cytogenetic response of the disease to the therapy.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A domain for disease response evaluations.

Concepts.definition: A domain for disease response evaluations.

Property.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Or Myelodysplastic Syndrome Cytogenetic Response
Property.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A clonal hematopoietic disorder characterized by dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in one or more of the hematopoietic cell lines. The dysplasia may be accompanied by an increase in myeloblasts, but the number is less than 20%, which, according to the WHO guidelines, is the requisite threshold for the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. It may occur de novo or as a result of exposure to alkylating agents and/or radiotherapy. (WHO, 2001):An evaluation of the cytogenetic response of the disease to the therapy.

Concepts.definition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

A clonal hematopoietic disorder characterized by dysplasia and ineffective hematopoiesis in one or more of the hematopoietic cell lines. The dysplasia may be accompanied by an increase in myeloblasts, but the number is less than 20%, which, according to the WHO guidelines, is the requisite threshold for the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. It may occur de novo or as a result of exposure to alkylating agents and/or radiotherapy. (WHO, 2001)
An evaluation of the cytogenetic response of the disease to the therapy.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities._The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may refer to eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression._A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.: Cancer that continues to grow or spread.

Concepts.definition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.
A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.: The return of a disease after a period of remission.

Concepts.definition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.: The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

Concepts.definition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.
The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.
Unable to be evaluated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Retained; never-ceasing.: An irregularity in the number or structure of chromosomes, usually in the form of a gain (duplication), loss (deletion), exchange (translocation), or alteration in sequence (inversion) of genetic material.

Concepts.definition: Retained; never-ceasing.

An irregularity in the number or structure of chromosomes, usually in the form of a gain (duplication), loss (deletion), exchange (translocation), or alteration in sequence (inversion) of genetic material.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.: Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No apparent change or worsening in tumor staging classification.

Concepts.definition: No apparent change or worsening in lesion staging classification.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being or affecting only a part of something.: An evaluation of the cytogenetic response of the disease to the therapy.

Concepts.definition: Being or affecting only a part of something.
An evaluation of the cytogenetic response of the disease to the therapy.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.:The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may refer to eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.
A condition or state at a particular time.
